description: From Middle English purgatorie, from Old French purgatore, purgatorie, from Latin purgātōrium (“cleansing”). Cognate to English purge.

adjectives.description: purgatory (comparative more purgatory, superlative most purgatory)

examples: Last of all, the prodigie of Siracusa was expiat by a purgatory sacrifice, by direction from the soothsaiers to what gods, supplications and sacrifice should be made.

entries.meaning: Any situation where suffering is endured, particularly as part of a process of redemption.
examples: […]  many Gods breedeth heathens miseries, many countries trauailers humors, many wiues mens purgatories, and many friends trustes ruine:
